header.title: The Hammer of Witches: A Complete Translation of the Malleus Maleficarum
header.category: Western Esotericism, Witchcraft Studies, Medieval Law, Demonology

central_thesis: Christopher S. Mackay's 'The Hammer of Witches' provides the first complete and reliable English translation of the Malleus Maleficarum, meticulously contextualizing its intellectual, cultural, and historical background. The core thesis of the Malleus itself is to establish and rigorously justify the existence of a new, diabolic conception of witchcraft ('Heresy of Sorceresses') as a grave threat to Christendom, and to provide comprehensive theological and legal methods for its detection, prosecution, and extermination.

structure_content.summary: This section provides an overview of the Malleus Maleficarum, detailing its authorship by Sprenger and Institoris, its purpose to popularize a new satanic conception of witchcraft, and its historical context including the role of printing, scholasticism, and the European witch hunts. It analyzes the Malleus's sources (Aquinas, Nider, Eymeric, Antoninus of Florence), its methodology (quaestio disputata), and its misogynistic portrayal of women. Critical analysis places the Malleus within an apocalyptic framework, discusses the role of divine permission in sorcery, and examines the historical realities of magical practices versus the elaborated theory of satanism.

structure_content.chapter_title: Part I: Proving the Existence of Sorcery (Malleus Maleficarum)
structure_content.summary: This part is organized into eighteen 'questions' that theoretically demonstrate the reality of sorcery. It asserts that belief in sorcerers is Catholic, refuting claims that their effects are imaginary. Key topics include the necessity of demonic cooperation, human procreation by incubus/succubus demons, the distinct nature of different unclean spirits, and the refutation of astrological influences or human evil as primary causes of sorcery. It dedicates significant attention to why women are more prone to sorcery, detailing various maleficent acts attributed to them (impeding procreation, removing male members, transforming humans into beasts, infanticide by midwives). The section concludes by asserting divine permission for sorcery as a just punishment for human sins and comparing sorcerers' crimes to those of demons and the First Ancestors.

structure_content.chapter_title: Part II: The Methods of Sorcery and Their Remedies (Malleus Maleficarum)
structure_content.summary: This part describes the actual practices of sorceresses and methods to counteract them. It is divided into two main sections: sorceresses' initiation and methods of working, and legitimate remedies. The first section covers how demons entice individuals into the 'Heresy of Sorceresses,' the sacrilegious avowal, bodily transportation by demons, subordination to incubus demons, using Church Sacraments for sorcery, impeding procreation, causing impotence, transforming humans into animals, and inflicting various illnesses (including those caused by midwife sorceresses and those affecting domestic animals and weather). The second section details lawful remedies, distinguishing them from unlawful ones, covering ecclesiastical remedies against demonic harassment, impediments to procreation, irregular love/hatred, illusions of removed male members or animal transformation, demonic possession, general illnesses, hailstorms, and other vexations.

structure_content.chapter_title: Part III: Judicial Extermination of Sorceresses (Malleus Maleficarum)
structure_content.summary: This part outlines the legal procedures for investigating, convicting, and punishing sorceresses, addressing both ecclesiastical and civil jurisdictions. It covers initiating proceedings, rules for witnesses (number, status, mortal enmity, concealment of identity), methods of examining the accused, and procedures for detention and torture (including strategies against the 'sorcery of silence'). The core focus is on the twenty methods of passing sentence based on various levels of suspicion (innocent, bad reputation, lightly, vehemently, violently suspected) and different stages of confession or relapse. It also addresses sentencing fugitives, those denounced by other sorceresses, and those attempting to break spells, as well as midwife sorceresses and male sorcerers, concluding with guidelines for handling appeals.

key_concepts.definition: A notorious medieval text on witchcraft, first published in 1486, serving to popularize the satanic/diabolic conception of witchcraft and providing extensive justifications and procedures for its persecution.

Practitioners of malevolent magic, specifically 'evil-doers' who inflict harm through sorcery and are adherents of the 'Heresy of Sorceresses'. These terms emphasize the harm caused and the diabolic pact.

Malevolent magic, understood as a heretical cult allied with Satan. It encompasses a range of activities including a pact with the Devil, sexual relations with demons, aerial flight to assemblies, maleficent magic, infanticide, and various harms to humans, animals, and crops. It can also refer to the physical items used or the effects produced.

A new conception of sorcery, distinct from traditional folk magic, positing a malevolent society presided over by Satan himself. Key elements include a pact with the Devil, sexual relations with demons, aerial flight to witch assemblies, the practice of maleficent magic, and the slaughter of babies. This concept was pivotal in instigating the witch hunts.

The standard scholastic argumentation method, structured with a title (the correct view), arguments for the incorrect view, contradictory evidence, a 'response' (the correct position and reasoning), and 'solutions of the arguments' (rebuttals to the initial false arguments).

A charge, such as sorcery, exempted from usual legal precautions, allowing for the application of extraordinary investigative measures, including torture, due to its perceived heinousness and threat to the Christian order.
The supposed ability of sorceresses, aided by demons, to endure torture without confessing by making themselves immune to pain. The text provides stratagems for judges to counteract this.

An ecclesiastical institution and its official (often a Dominican friar) responsible for investigating and prosecuting heresy. In the context of the Malleus, inquisitors were empowered to deal with sorcery as a form of heretical depravity, often seeking the assistance of secular authorities for punishment.

An official letter issued by Pope Innocent VIII in 1484, confirming and amplifying the authority of Institoris and Sprenger as inquisitors into heretical depravity, specifically against sorcery, thereby legitimizing their actions against local opposition.

The medieval term for 'corpse divination,' often confused with the Latin 'niger' (black). It refers to 'black arts' involving explicit invocation of demons, distinguished from common sorcery but still considered heretical and subject to severe penalties.

A form of penance where an accused person with a bad reputation for heresy must clear their name through an oath, supported by a specified number of compurgators (reputable individuals who attest to their innocence).

An individual who returns to heresy after having previously abjured it. Such persons are subject to more severe penalties, including being handed over to the secular arm for execution (typically burning alive), regardless of subsequent repentance.

practical_system.description: The Malleus Maleficarum is not a practical grimoire for a magician to perform spells. Instead, it functions as an operative manual for the ecclesiastical and civil authorities to detect, investigate, counteract, and prosecute 'sorceresses' (maleficae) who are believed to have entered into a diabolic pact. The 'system' outlines a framework based on demonological theory, scholastic argumentation, and legal procedures (rooted in Roman and Canon law) to systematically dismantle witchcraft, understood as a direct assault by Satan on God's creation. Its operative side is focused on methods of identification, legal proof (including torture), and the ritualistic and judicial extermination of individuals accused of this heretical depravity.
tools: Religious Objects: Holy Water, Holy Salt, Blessed Plants/Fronds, Consecrated Candles, Sacraments (Eucharist, Confession), Sign of the Cross.

Amulets/Written Chants: Pieces of paper with Sacred Words (Lord's Prayer, Hail Mary, John 1:1, Mark 16:17-18, Triumphal Title of the Savior, Five Wounds of Christ, Three Nails of Christ, Four Evangelists) carried on the person.
Sorcery Devices: Wax images, aromatic objects, specific plants, animal parts (e.g., snakes), bones, kernels, seeds, threads, buried under thresholds or in specific locations.

Diagnostic Tools: Molten lead poured into water (to reveal images of sorcery's cause), physician's judgment (to distinguish sorcery from natural illness, based on pulse/temperament changes, sudden onset, lack of natural cure).
Judicial Implements: Chains, fetters, torture devices (e.g., strappado), written protocols, official seals.
rituals: Initiation of Sorceresses: Renunciation of Catholic Faith, solemn self-dedication (body and soul) to the Devil, offering unbaptized babies to demons, engaging in carnal acts with incubus/succubus demons.

Infliction of Sorcery: Using various external objects (thorns, bones, hair, wood) or internal methods (influencing imagination/humors) to cause illnesses, impede procreation, remove male members (illusion), transform humans into beasts, harm domestic animals, or cause hailstorms/lightning. This is done through a pact with a demon, often with specific words or actions.

Counteracting Sorcery (Lawful): Making the Sign of the Cross, reciting the Lord's Prayer and Hail Mary, consuming Holy Salt and Water, using blessed plants/wax tapers, performing lawful exorcisms, receiving Sacramental Confession, visiting holy places, and engaging in devout prayers and fasts.

Counteracting Sorcery (Unlawful/Tolerated): Employing superstitious remedies without explicit demonic invocation (e.g., specific plants, words, figures) or using 'vain acts' to break other 'vain acts' (e.g., smashing a pitcher to stop milk-stealing sorcery), though the latter is viewed as dangerous.

Judicial Process: Summoning witnesses, administering oaths, examining witnesses (often with names concealed), interrogating the accused, applying moderate torture (continued over days but not repeated), using stratagems to break the 'sorcery of silence' (e.g., shaving the body, using blessed wax in drinks), imposing canonical purgation, public or private abjuration, and ultimately sentencing for execution (burning alive for impenitent/relapsed heretics or temporal losses).

relevant_quotes.text: The Malleus Maleficarum, first published in 1486, is the standard medieval text on witchcraft and it remained in print throughout the early modern period. Its descriptions of the evil acts of witches and the ways to exterminate them continue to contribute to our knowledge of early modern law, religion and society.

The present work offers the reader the only full and reliable translation of the Malleus into English, and this introduction has a very specific purpose: to set out for the reader the general intellectual and cultural background of the Malleus...
The great persecutions of sorcery that lasted from the fifteenth until the early seventeenth centuries were based upon a new notion of sorcery that can be termed “satanism” (or “diabolism”).
The Malleus has been characterized as a thoroughly misogynistic work, and (to borrow a mode of argument from scholasticism) this is true or not depending on what one means by misogyny.

The use of torture arose in conjunction with the revival of Roman law that started in the eleventh century in Italy and gradually spread to the north... Basically, torture was prohibited unless there was a reasonably strong prima facie case against the suspect, and it could be applied only twice.
The major significance of the Malleus lies in the role it played in the dissemination and widespread acceptance of the elaborated theory of witchcraft.

The Malleus can safely be used as a guide to the understanding of sorcery held in the mid to late fifteenth century by certain members of the elite. It is very difficult to consider the anecdotal material in the work as shedding unfiltered light on popular beliefs and practices.

The Devil knows that unbaptized children are not allowed into the kingdom of heaven and thus the consummation of the world and the day of judgment that will see the Devil cast into eternal perdition will be put off.

critical_analysis.relevance: Christopher S. Mackay's 'The Hammer of Witches' is an indispensable academic resource for understanding the historical phenomenon of European witch hunts. It provides a meticulously translated primary source, the Malleus Maleficarum, which served as a foundational text for the systematic persecution of alleged witches. The accompanying scholarly apparatus contextualizes the Malleus within its intellectual, theological, and legal milieu, revealing how scholastic reasoning and existing legal procedures were adapted to justify the 'elaborated concept of witchcraft.' This work highlights the profound impact of institutionalized demonology on legal practices, contributing to mass hysteria and revealing the mechanisms by which religious and secular authorities sought to control perceived threats to social and religious order. For practitioners of Western Esotericism, it offers a stark historical counterpoint, illustrating how folk magical practices and evolving theological concepts were reinterpreted through a demonological lens, leading to devastating consequences for those accused of sorcery.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience includes scholars and students of medieval and early modern history, particularly those specializing in the history of law, religion, gender studies, and witchcraft. Researchers in Western Esotericism and occult studies will find it crucial for understanding the historical perception and persecution of magical practices. Additionally, legal historians, theologians, and general readers interested in the 'witch craze' and the social dynamics of fear and belief will find this translation and analysis highly informative.
